comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: I can barely make out the date on Pall Mall magazine, but it might be July 1905. Or maybe 1906. "The Royal" in his hand, does say July on the cover. Pretty heavy coat for July though. Found a picture of the June 1905 Pall Mall, but I think they all had the same cover design.

Davy Stephens Snippets from Freeman's 1882-1899
Davy Stephens Fund Feb 1 1882 Davy Stephens' "Kiosk" Dec 14 1883 Davy Stephens biographical sketch in handy booklet form July 10 1889 Surely NLI has a copy? "Yachting World" special July 21 1894 The Duke of York and Davy Stephens Dec 24 1895 Davy Stephens debate in the House of Commons July 22 1899

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Shirley, A longer article from the Huddersfield Daily Chronicle April 19 1882 - Davy Stephens - People I have met Includes these gems and many more
'Davy' is proud of his calling, and the only regret he has in connection with it is that he did not succeed in making quite as much money as his distinguished colleague, W. H. Smith
and
I met the queen on her second visit. That time she was a low-sized woman with a large full face, and nothing much to look at

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The kangaroo playing cricket must be a reference to the Ashes tour which was going on that summer. England won the series 2-0, RH Spooner making his debut during the 4th test at Old Trafford.

comment._content:
There are evidently a couple of references to Davy Stevens in James Joyce's "Ulysses",  which I am having trouble finding.  Help please, literary experts!

Also his birth and death dates? ... he looks about 60 here.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Good Guess! A paragraph in The Penny Illustrated Paper and Illustrated Times of June 10 1905 (i.e 1 month before the photo) states that he "is now sixty-one", which would make his birth year 1844 or thereabouts. The description of him with "long locks and weather-beaten complexion" matches the photo. "Sir" Davy

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In the photo on this website it looks as if he's wearing the same coat (and possibly shirt and tie) as in the photo above.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
From www.joyceimages.com
A colorful character, Davy wrote an autobiography titled 'The Life and Times of Davy Stephens: the renowned Kingstown Newsman' where he describes himself thus: "His exterior is peculiar but prepossessing. Standing a little below the usual height for the proverbial Irishman, this point is quickly lost sight of in a deep well of wit, not yet completely sounded, beaming forth in his eyes. No one can say whether it is in the merry glance of his eye or in the quick repartee that issues from his lips, never for a moment sealed, that Davy's fortune lies. The corners of his mouth are turned up in a perpetual smile which his clean shaven chin tends to emphasise. [...] His hair hangs down over his shoulders in long strings, reminding one of that of Ulysses when tossed by the sea at the feet of the charming Nausicaa, and the fresh breezes of the Channel has reduced his complexion to a compromise between red and brown. In a black frieze overcoat and a soft Trilby hat he braves the cross-Channel gales in winter as readily as be broils beneath the portico of the railway station when the temperature is only 88 degrees in the shade. Atmospheric variations seemingly exert no influence on the perfect constitution of Davy. The scent of the briny and the glint of the sunshine are alike to him. Add to these particulars a fine rich brogue and the man is complete."

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Thank you. There are enough anecdotes about Davy Stephens to keep us going for years. Even in the Australian contemporary newspapers - trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/result?q=%22Davy+Stephens%22 , including this one of his death on 11/9/1925 "aged 84", which means born in 1841 ?? - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/64249519 And the "Ulysses" quote -
"The door of Ruttledge's office creaked again. Davy Stephens, minute in a large capecoat, a small felt hat crowning his ringlets, passed out with a roll of papers under his cape, a king's courier." (U7.28)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The London times, in a short  paragraph announcing his death, isn't much help:  "about 80". It also says he was a total abstainer from alcohol and tobacco.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: You can contact Davy Stephens but he might not reply

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] 58 in 1901: www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Dublin/Kingstow.... Which makes him 82 or 83 in 1925 (I don't know when the census was taken and I couldn't be bothered looking it up).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From the Irish Independent, Friday, 13 May 1910 (following the death of Edward VII):
Davy Stephens, Kingstown, has received the following replies:- "Queen Alexandra sends you her sincere thanks for your kind message of sympathy in her sorrow." "The Equerry-in-Waiting is commanded by the King to thank Mr. Davy Stephens for his loyal and sympathetic message of condolence."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 34283595@N00
comment._content: If you look closely you will see a copy of my grandfather's publication 'The Lepraucan'. Davy was a great pal of his and a great teller of tall tales, like my grandfather, Thomas FitzPatrick, writer, artist and publisher of the fortnightly magazine. James Joyce used to write captions and copy for him and subscribed to the Lepraucan until it ceased publication. He knew Davy well too, hence the appearance in Ulysses. Jim FitzPatrick. Artist.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jimfitzpatrick] Hello Jim, and thanks for your lovely information. We are very big fans of your grandfather and The Lepracaun around here, and some images from that great publication are currently appearing in our Dublin Lockout exhibition. We have some works by Thomas FitzPatrick in our collections - some digitised and some not yet. This is one of my favourites...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
